headline.main: STOKES QUITTING NEW YORK?; After Los Angeles Hotel, Is Report, but His Counsel Hears Nothing.

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

docs.abstract: W E D Stokes rumored trying to buy Los Angeles hotel
docs.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Cal., Jan. 3. -- Negotiations for the purchase of the Hotel Lankershaim by W.E.D. Stokes, lately owner of the Ansonia Hotel in New York, are said to be under way, following the visit here of Harold B. Wirt, a representative of Mr. Stokes. Mr. Wirt has already held consultations with Col. J.B. Lankershaim, the owner, and Edward Davis, manager of the hotel.

headline.main: HOTEL PORTERS OUT, STRIKE FOR TIPS; Revolt Against System of Turning All Gifts Over to the Head Porter. BAGGAGE HANDLING DELAY Bellboys and Clerks Pressed Into Service -- Some Hotels Yield to the Strikers.

docs.abstract: NYC hotel porters strike; protest practice of turning all tips over to head porter
docs.lead_paragraph: There were only two or three first-class hotels in New York which at 8 o'clock yesterday morning had even a single porter to handle the baggage of arriving and departing guests. The porters had gone on strike. The tip is the bone of contention, the porters declaring that all gratuities should go to the persons to whom they are given, the hotels maintaining that all fees should go to the head porter.

headline.main: HIGGINS TO BE ASKED TO EXCLUDE HOTEL BAR; Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church to Send Protesting Committees. NEW GOTHAM IS OPPOSITE Saxe Bill Is Said to Have Been Passed to Allow the Sale of Liquor There.

docs.lead_paragraph: Committees representing the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church will go to Albany to-day to plead with Gov. Higgins not to sign the Saxe Bill, which they assert was introduced sorely for the purpose of legalizing liquor selling at the new Hotel Gotham. The hotel is on Fifty-fifth Street directly opposite the church.

headline.main: HOTEL BRESLIN OPENS.; Hostelry on Sturtevant House Site Ready for Guests.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Hotel Breslin, a new eleven-story structure at the southeast corner of Broadway and Twenty-eighth Street, which has been building for a year past at a cost of about $1,000,000, was formerly opened last night. It is owned by a company, of which James H. Breslin, one-time owner of the Gilsey House, and who recently built the Hotel Wolcott, at the corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-second Street, is the President.
